sentence: Global IT services provider, Accenture plcACN , recently announced the acquisition of CRMWaypoint, a cloud advisory and technology service supplier especially of salesforce.com Inc.'s CRM cloud solutions for sales, service and marketing across the Netherlands.
However, the financial terms of the transaction have not been disclosed.
The recent move is probably part of Accenture's strategy of strengthening its position across the Netherlands as a provider of Salesforce services and cloud implementations.
Founded in 2006 with an exclusive focus on Salesforce, CRMWaypoint has emerged as one of the largest Salesforce partners in Benelux.
Over the years, the company has served clients in medium as well as large market segments and delivered on more than 600 Salesforce projects across various industries.

As per Accenture's press release "With the acquisition, CRMWaypoint's professionals have joined the Accenture Cloud First Applications team, which delivers cloud services for Salesforce, Workday, ServiceNow, Google and other "pure play" cloud technologies."

With this buyout, Accenture will be able to leverage the latest technology, provide enhanced performance and strengthen its position as a global leader in cloud-based applications as well as Salesforce services.
The acquisition will also help Accenture to improve its customer relationships and expand market share by solving business critical issues.
Notably, Accenture is already a global leader in providing Salesforce implementation services and currently has over 5,000 Salesforce consultants of which more than 1,900 are certified.
Moreover, as Salesforce is one of the largest providers of cloud-based applications and software, it becomes necessary for Accenture to enhance its capabilities in delivering the former's services.
Over the past couple of years, demand for cloud-based software and applications is on the rise.

According to Centaur Partners, the SaaS and cloud-based business applications are likely to grow from $13.5 billion in 2013 to $32.8 billion in 2016, reflecting a compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) of 19.5%.
Moreover, Computerworld forecasts that 42% of IT decision makers are planning to increase spending on cloud computing in 2015.
The exponential growth in the amount of data, complexity of data formats and the need to scale resources at regular intervals compelled several companies to turn to cloud computing vendors.
Therefore, considering the growing need for cloud-based applications and software, we expect Accenture's investments in this space to boost long-term growth.
Accenture resorts to strategic acquisitions to diversify its offerings and expand operating markets.
Last month, the company completed three acquisitions while in 2015, it bought 21 companies.
A strong cash balance of $4.36 billion, operating cash flow of $4.09 billion and free cash flow of $3.7 billion at the end of fiscal 2015 supports the company's inorganic growth strategy.
These acquisitions have enabled Accenture to enter newer markets, diversify and broaden the product portfolio and maintain a leading position.
We believe that the company's regular acquisitions will significantly contribute to the revenue stream.
However, we remain slightly cautious about the intensifying competition and an uncertain IT spending environment, which may undermine the company's near-term performance.
Currently, Accenture carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).
A couple of better-ranked stocks in the broader technology sector are Integrated Device Technology Inc. IDTI and Mellanox Technologies, Ltd. MLNX , both sporting a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).
